reviews.title: Very cool mall!
text: Brookfield Place is a huge mall next to the Hockey Hall of Fame in Toronto. There are so many stores, souvenir shops, and restaurants here such as Tim Hortons, Roots, and of course, the Hockey Hall of Fame. I highly recommend shopping here.

reviews.title: Great roof
text: I came across purely by chance but what an amazing place. If interested in architecture just to see the most incredible roof is worth the visit.

reviews.title: Accessible
text: This building is connected to other attractions, particularly hockey hall of fame. In the winter, you may use this building as a temporary shelter from cold weather. This place is well accessible via public transportation or on foot from other attractions.

reviews.title: Worth walking through
text: I walked through Brookfield Place in May 2022.  It is an impressive place to walk through.  The architecture is very interesting and you can stop and rest.  There is a Tim Horton's where you can get coffee and also a convenience store.  Also the entrance to the Hockey Hall of Fame.

reviews.title: Everything is super aesthetic.
text: This is one of those buildings in Toronto I always manage to find myself in and can't quite figure out how, but I love walking through it, and take photos of EVERYTHING!

reviews.title: Worth a visit
text: The building’s exterior may not attract you, but make sure to go inside and admire the architecture. Definitely worth a visit. Stop at Marche for lunch, or just walk through the gigantic hall

reviews.title: Nice to look at for a few minutes
text: I went here on a walking tour.  Interesting architecture and worth the visit if you are nearby but I wouldn't go out of my way to see it.

reviews.title: Stunning architecture
text: Built over a former street and enclosing the preserved facade of a heritage building this is one of the hidden architectural delights. The soaring buttresses of the atrium provide a totally unique visit experience. It is the home of a food court and restaurants and a location for rotating exhibitions and events. Close to theatre and the Canadian Hockey Hall of Fame and many eating options.

reviews.title: Beautiful building in Toronto that shouldn't be missed.
text: Always enjoy being here. Nice restaurants and the architecture shouldn't be missed if touring downtown Toronto. There is a large Marche restaurant at the end or down the escalator are many restaurants and the Hockey Hall of Fame.

reviews.title: Customer Service
text: Starbucks is usually known for service but after my last visit, I’m not so sure. Ordered a double smoked bacon sandwich. It was a sloppy job. The way it was packaged, the person definitely didn’t seem to care. This is not the first time. When it happened before, I thought maybe the staff was having a bad day. It has become more frequent. Very disappointed.

reviews.title: Beautiful Architecture, shops and restaurants
text: This is a beautiful piece of architecture on the main (street) level. At this level you will find an old bank building that has been incorporated into the modern building as well as a good restaurant and several shops including an excellent newsstand. On the lower lever is a good food court and more shops that are worth looking at. There is also a drug store on this level. The Hockey Hall of Fame is accessible via this building.

reviews.title: Nice place to walk through
text: The architecture is very interesting. We went on a weekend afternoon and a number of the shops in the food court/lower level were closed so if you can, it may be best to go on a weekday.

reviews.title: Wonderful for a walk through on your way to the Sony Centre or St. Lawrence Market!!!
text: Brookfield place is right at Front and Yonge and "the Path" (underground) runs right under it, but to see it in all its' glory you have to go to the main floor to see the arches and architecture.  It is built around an old brink bank building and is absolutely beautiful.

reviews.title: More Impressed with the food court
text: May 11/18 and after my visit to the Hockey Hall Of Fame hunger set in and I found such a variety of food and beverage choices it was difficult to make a choice. Very clean and modern and also very busy.

reviews.title: Amazing photo opps!
text: You will love the way the light seeps through the indoor arches of this spot.  It makes for some truly great photos!  However, there are only two reasons I am here in this space - to go to Movenpick - a lovely restaurant and there are others, but mainly to go to the Hockey Hall of Fame which is connected in the lower level to this Brookfield Place.

reviews.title: Great
text: It's a great place, so beautiful, nice architecture. It's a business place, but still a very beautiful one.

reviews.title: Don't miss it - whether you are interested in modern architecture or not.
text: I visit Toronto once a year.  i worked in Toronto twice - 8 years each time.  Each time I visit I must walk through the complex from Bay St. to Yonge St.  There is a bus on Bay St. and, of course, the subway on Yonge St. (exit at King and walk south.

reviews.title: Interesting architecture.. great photo subject
text: Cool way to connect the buildings.. Walk through and enjoy the airy feel of the atrium and see the old bank storefront and be sure to admire the oasis and note the "palm tree" structures that surround it. Great for abstract architecture photos..
If you are wandering around downtown TO, walk through and check it out..
You can find several shops and restaurants as well as the Hockey Hall of Fame.

reviews.title: The World Press Photo Exhibition is a must see!
text: Make sure you get down here before October 25th so you can see it for yourself. Its completely free and opens your eyes to everything that has happened this year without the bias of local governments and bribed media outlets. Some of it is hard to stomach but it is even harder to forget. Its interesting, informative and a must-see for any truth seekers out there. As for the setting, what a beautiful building and its also complete with food and drink if you needed to see and read every single exhibit as i did.

reviews.title: Walked through it on our way to the Hockey Hall of Fame
text: I had no idea what we were walking into on our way to the hockey hall of fame, but it's worth a mention.  It functions as a mall of sorts with plenty of places to eat, sip a coffee, and shop but it's gorgeous!  High glass archways throughout and a preserved old building forms part of the facade of the main hallway.  Really nice surprise.

reviews.title: Quick Bite
text: A fantastic place to get a quick bite to eat in a beautiful atrium!  Quite a few places to choose from both upstairs and downstairs.

reviews.title: Old and new
text: A modern steel structure with arches which represent trees and their branches towers above an older RBC building which was moved stone by stone inside to preserve it.
Very quiet at weekend, not much is open and they even stop the escalators from working!

reviews.title: It's OK
text: A nice atrium but nothing that you would go out of your way to see.  It contains a couple of restaurants, Ki, Café Marche and a Tim Horton's.  Also several retailers, including Roots and the entrance to the Hockey Hall of Fame.  More of a transit passage than a tourist destination.

reviews.title: Pretty ceiling
text: This is a greta place to stop in on your way to or from something, but I expected more based on reviews. The hockey hall of fame is here along with some shopping and food choices. My kids did love riding the escalators up and down.

reviews.title: Beautiful ceiling
text: Brookfield Palce has been around for quite sometime- I remember this place in the 90s. But it still looks great with the arches to the ceiling that reveal natural light from the outside. You can get to,the Hockey hall of fame by taking this route as well as find restaurants and shops too. Good place to visit even it just walking through.

reviews.title: Unexpected find on the way to The Hockey Hall of Fame...
text: As we were on our way to the Hockey Hall of Fame, we found this place unexpectedly. It was pretty cool to take-in all the arching columns and the design. It is a great photo opportunity, especially when it is sunny out. The light passes through the top of the arches and it is somewhat reminiscent of the cathedrals in Europe.

reviews.title: Nice impressive place
text: This is a nice and impressive place, with lots of opportunities to make shopping or to eat something.

reviews.title: Very interesting architecture
text: Houses the Hockey hall of fame but also many shops and eating places. Definitely wrthwhile a glimpse.

reviews.title: A showcase of beautiful modern architecture
text: Brookfield Place is a true showcase of beautiful modern architecture. We live in Toronto and whenever we have guests from out of town or especially out of the country, we are so proud to show them the site and see their reaction. It's absolutely incredible!

reviews.title: Classy Place
text: Nice design. good place to visit. Nice stores, on underground city. Marche is a good restaurant to spend some time in.

reviews.title: Love it
text: Love visiting here. Always something different going on.  A good variety of shops and eateries. Access to hockey hall of fame here as well.

reviews.title: Must Walk - Toronto's Financial District
text: Just north of front between Bay and Yonge Street - a short block from Union Station.

Nicest lobby/galleria of all Toronto Towers (Scotia Plaza a close second). Home to Marche, the Hocket Hall of Fame and Hocket themed Tim Horton's and my favorite newspaper stand on the Yonge Street Side.
Please dont miss it and please let me know, if you liked it!!

reviews.title: Cool office tower for people who love architecture
text: The architecture is quite interesting if you have a keen eye for that sort of thing. A place for office workers only. Allocate about 15 minutes to walk inside.

reviews.title: Architectual Icon of Toronto
text: The great hall is often shown on TV shots of Toronto. So it is worth a few minutes of wandering about to just look at it. At ground level, it is an office building so, aside from walking through the hall, there isn't all the much else to see.

But you can also visit the Hockey Hall of Fame which is right there. And there are some restaurants and a Moven Pick below. So if you are in the mood to eat, it is right there as well. It is also on The Path (network of underground walkways that extends from Union Station to the Eaton's Centre).

It is an office building so at lunch time you'll see all the office worker disgourge from their offices to quickly eat their lunch and then dash back to work. If you want, you can sit there and watch and take some pleasure in the thought that, hey, as a tourist, you don't need to rush.

You will be at Yonge + Front Street, so you aren't that far from Union Station (another interesting interior to look at which you can get to via The Path -- If you see someone who doesn't look too busy, you can ask how to get there -- as well as the lake and the Island ferries.
This isn't something you need to go a great deal out of your way to see. However if you are nearby, it is worth a look.

reviews.title: BEAUTIFUL ARCHITECTURE ABOVE GROUND ~ FOOD & SHOPPING MALL UNDERGROUND
text: While visiting Canadian friends with some friends from home, we went on daytrips to Toronto twice, using the GO Train from Aldershot Train Station in Burlington.  The train goes into Union Station in a section of the Financial District in Downtown Toronto on Front Street.
In touring the district, we soon found ourselves at Brookfield Place after visiting the Toronto Dominion Gallery of Intuit Art.
It’s an office complex in Downtown Toronto in the Financial District.  It's boundaries are Yong Street, Wellington Street West, Bay Street, and Front Street.
The building's architecture is something to appreciate.

But, there’s a lot more to Brookfield Place than a tall building.  There’s a mall hidden from sight underneath.  In the past, I’ve seen this in other large Canadian cities, such La Ville Souterraine, / The Underground City in Montréal, and the CF Pacific Centre in Vancouver.

The ground level has the Allen Lambert Galleria, Sam Pollock Square, Garden Court, and the  Hockey Hall of Fame.  The Allen Lambert Galleria has a massive glass and steel dome that ranges six stories high.   Sam Pollock Square is connected to the Galleria and has huge curved arches that fan out in four directions to support its dome.  Both were designed by the famous architect Santiago Calatrava.
The biggest attractions for most visitors are the shopping and dining.
We did not spend a lot of time here as a group.  It was more of a walk-through.  I returned later when we had about two hours of free time on our own late in the afternoon.

There is limited shopping on the ground floor.  Spirit of Hockey, a retail gift store is on the ground floor along with Gateway Newstands, Pace Men's Collection, and Roots, a lifestyle store for men and women.  The Hockey Hall of Fame is also on this level.
The restaurants are on the lower concourse which connects to Union Station via the PATH.
Stores on the lower concourse that I browsed included:
·  Crème de la Crème, a European lingerie and swimwear boutique
·  STEPSS,  a trendy shoe store
·  Nutrition House
·  Papyrus, a card store with candles, gifts, and stationery
·  Shoppers Drug Mart
·  The Source by Circuit City for a full line of electronics

Dining options were mostly of the fast food type for the business crowd.  Most offered much healthier food than what’s offered in the United Sates for fast food.  The names of places I saw included Early Bird Coffee & Kitchen, Jelly, Extreme Pita, Lahuna Poke Stop, Manchu Wok, a Greenhouse juicery, Kupfert & Kim, iQ Food Company, Piazza Manna, Mucho Burrito,  The Bagel Stop, Pumpernickel's sandwich shop, Soup It Up,  The Market by Longo’s, Jimmy the Greek, Nori Japan, Marché Mövenpick for artisan breads, and Paramount Fine Foods, a Mediterranean restaurant.
Also, McDonald’s, Tim Horton’s, Subway, and Starbucks were there.  But, why bother with the commonplace when there are so many new places with healthier fare to try?
There were a number of companies in the services sector that included all the major car rental companies, a dry cleaner, Transit Travel, Canada Trust Bank,  Onyx Nail Salon, and Jo’s Shoe Repair.
My friends and I appreciated the beautiful architecture of the Allen Lambert Galleria and Sam Pollock Square, but I really liked the underground mall more.
We rate it at 4.75 and recommend a visit.

reviews.title: Tons of shops and underground
text: Used to be such a nice place back in the days when it opened. Now there is nothing to WOW you to wanna be here except the shops and eatery downstairs

reviews.title: Beauty Galore
text: I personally love Brookfield Place.  It is magnificent with its high ceiling and beautiful architecture. I rat this building with Casa Loma, Royal York Hotel, Union Station and Old City Hall. I love old buildings because they have class and were built with lots of love. Today, everything is about money so many people have forgotten LOVE. I will go to this building everytime I can and just stare at the ceiling. I take pictures of the building which is also a part of the oldest bank, new banks and part of the underground shopping mall. You must visit this place. There is some amazing works of art on display at the present time. I have been there three thimes this week already. I love this place. I wish I could live in this building.

reviews.title: Beautiful place
text: A beautiful place to catch your breathe in this amazing city, plenty of places to sit and grab a snack or drink and the interior design is beautiful, well worth a pit-stop.

reviews.title: Good Meeting Place and Nice Building
text: This building is an easy walk from Union Station especially if you use the PATH walkway. Just keep left out of Union Station. On the lower concourse you will find a food court with a McDonalds and others, a drug store and about a dozen other stores. The entrance to the Canadian Hockey Hall of Fame is located in one corner of this concourse.  Take the escalator up and you see some very attractive architecture in the building. The street level is dominated by sweeping arches and open space. It also contains the façade of an old bank building. Art exhibits are often held here. There is a nice restaurant at one end and an adjacent news stand. A good place to meet people is in the open area just outside the LaMarche restaurant.

reviews.title: Attractive architecture
text: Sam Pollock Square, located in the atrium of Brookfield Place, is an attractive piece of urban architecture. There are restaurants and coffee shops around the edge, and an escalator takes you down to a food court and the entrance to the Hockey Hall of Fame. Worth a visit.
